skills.name: Calculate the square of a number
Calculate the cube of a number

explanations.A: A square number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself. 1 x 1 is 1 so 1 is a square number.
explanations.B: Not quite. We do use a little 2 to represent that a number is being squared, e.g. 3², but 2 itself is not a square number
explanations.C: I think you have mixed up square numbers and cube numbers. You get a square number if you multiply any whole number by itself.
explanations.D: There is a square number as one of these options. Think of the first few square numbers you know.

explanations.A: Not quite. You get a square number if you multiply any whole number by itself.
explanations.B: Not quite. You get a square number if you multiply any whole number by itself.
explanations.C: A square number is the result when you multiply a number by itself. 3 x 3 is 9 so 9 is a square number.
explanations.D: There is a square number as one of these options. Think of the first few square numbers you know.

explanations.A: A cube number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself and then by itself again. 1 x 1 x 1 is 1 so 1 is a cube number.
explanations.B: Not quite. We do use a little 3 to represent that a number is being cubed, e.g. 2³, but 3 itself is not a cube number.
explanations.C: Not quite. 9 is a multiple of 3, but not a cube number. A cube number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself and then by itself again.
explanations.D: There is a cube number as one of these options. Think of the first few cube numbers you know.

explanations.A: We do use a little 3 to represent that a number is being cubed, e.g. 2³, but 3 itself is not a cube number.
explanations.B: 6 is a multiple of 3, but not a cube number. A cube number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself and then by itself again
explanations.C: Not quite. 9 is a multiple of 3, but not a cube number. A cube number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself and then by itself again.
explanations.D: A cube number is the result when you multiply a whole number by itself and then by itself again e.g. 1x1x1=1, 2x2x2=8, 3x3x3=27. 1, 8 and 27 are the first 3 cube numbers. The list of cube numbers does not include 3, 6 or 9.

explanations.A: Not quite. We do use a 2 to write '8 squared' but this is a superscript 2 and looks like 8². Instead, here we need to work out the answer when we square 8.
explanations.B: I think you might have just written the digit 8 twice. '8 squared' means 8 multiplied by itself.
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you have multiplied 8 by 2. To square a number, we need to multiply it by itself.
explanations.D: 8 squared means 8 multiplied by itself or 8 x 8. This gives us an answer of 64.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have multiplied 7 by 2. To square a number, we need to multiply it by itself.
explanations.B: 7 squared means 7 multiplied by itself or 7 x 7. This gives us an answer of 49.
explanations.C: Not quite. We do use a 2 to write '7 squared' but this is a superscript 2 and looks like 7². Instead, here we need to work out the answer when we square 7.
explanations.D: I think you might have just written the digit 7 twice. 7 squared means 7 multiplied by itself.

explanations.A: I think you have mixed up your squares and cubes. To cube a number, we need to multiply it by itself and then by itself again.
explanations.B: 3 cubed means 3 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again, or 3 x 3 x 3. This gives us an answer of 27.
explanations.C: I think you might have just written the digit 3 twice. 3 cubed means 3 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again.
explanations.D: I think you might have just written the digit 3 out 3 times. 3 cubed means 3 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again.

explanations.A: Not quite. We do use a little 3 to represent that a number is being cubed, but this is a superscript 3 and looks like 4³. Instead, here we need to work out the answer when we cube 4.
explanations.B: I think you have mixed up your squares and cubes. To cube a number, we need to multiply it by itself and then by itself again.
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied 4 by 3. When we cube a number, we have to multiply it by itself and itself again, not multiply it by 3.
explanations.D: 4 cubed means 4 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again, or 4 x 4 x 4. This gives us an answer of 64.

explanations.A: I think you have multiplied 5 by 3. When we cube a number, we have to multiply it by itself and itself again, not multiply it by 3.
explanations.B: I think you have mixed up your squares and cubes. To cube a number, we need to multiply it by itself and then by itself again.
explanations.C: 5 cubed means 5 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again, or 5 x 5 x 5. This gives us an answer of 125.
explanations.D: Not quite. We do use a little 3 to represent that a number is being cubed, but this is a superscript 3 and looks like 5³. Instead, here we need to work out the answer when we cube 5.

explanations.A: 2³ means 2 multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again, or 2 x 2 x 2. This gives us an answer of 8.
explanations.B: Not quite. We do use a little 3 to represent that a number is being cubed, but this is a superscript 3 and looks like 2³. Instead, here we need to work out the answer when we cube 2
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied 2 by 3. When we cube a number, we have to multiply it by itself and itself again, not multiply it by 3.
explanations.D: I think you have mixed up your squares and cubes. To cube a number, we need to multiply it by itself and then by itself again.
